stories.text:
Say, I have three entity types `Senior`, `Junior_A` and `Junior_B`. Each entity specifies access control for other entities. So I can either create tables as follows:

    Senior, Junior_A, Junior_B, AccessControl
where `AccessControl` holds access control details between all the entities. This simplifies the code but could lead to performance issues as everything is put into one table.

But, then I can also create the tables as follows:

    Senior, Junior_A, Junior_B, AC_Senior_Senior, AC_Senior_Junior_A, AC_Senior_Junior_B, AC_Junior_A_Junior_A, AC_Junior_A_Junior_B, AC_Junior_B_Junior_B

 where `AC_ABC_XYZ` is a table that holds access control information between entities `ABC` and `XYZ`. This complicates the code as the code now has to handle different tables depending on the entity types involved, but will improve performance.
Which design would you prefer, and why?
stories.title: Separate tables or just one table to hold access control info between entities?
